name: Functions of Government
description: How can building an understanding of legislation and policy help you to be an effective leader? How can you go beyond Gov 101 to deepen your knowledge of the functions of government and find out how major government initiatives impact your role and those you lead or may lead in the future? Follow this pathway to understand what you need to know now.
objective: Be equipped with foundational knowledge of the functions of government, both with respect to your own role and organization and across government.

steps.name: Step 1
steps.description: Research your government and your ministrys organizational structure. Discover who/what roles is/are in your branch, ministry, government.

activities.name: Ministry Intranets
activities.description:
A Ministry intranet is the key to each employee getting to know their Ministry org chart - divisions, branches etc. Every Ministry intranet has this information on it, so you can learn about other ministries here. You can find the Intranets for each Ministry by going to the Compass site, and selecting the org chart icon from the top navigation.

Note: Your ministry may not have a posted org chart. Ask around to see if you can access one on your orgs LAN.

activity_type.name: Read
activity_type.description: From real paper books to study abstracts and blog posts; the classic written word enhancing your learning in many ways.

activities.name: BC Government Organizational Structure
activities.description:
This is part of the government information on www.gov.bc.ca. It outlines the organizational structure of the BC government.

Through different links, you will learn about: Lieutenant Governor, Office of the Premier, Cabinet, Legislative Assembly, Ministries and Orgs, Public Service and Financial Disclosure. There are many links for future exploration and shows where useful info such as the parliamentary calendar can be found.

This is a great place to start building your foundation in the structure of the provincial government. The amount of time you spend will range considerably based on how many links you pursue.

This is an excellent reference to keep for future use.

activity_type.name: Read
activity_type.description: From real paper books to study abstracts and blog posts; the classic written word enhancing your learning in many ways.

activities.name: Gov 101 on @Work
activities.description:
Gov 101 is an evolving resource on @work that outlines government processes and how they affect the work of the public service. They include: Budget Day, Elections, Estimates, The Financial Cycle, The Legislative Assembly of BC, Making Laws, The Oath of Employment, The Speech from the Throne, Lieutenant Governor.

This is an excellent reference to keep for future use.

activity_type.name: Read
activity_type.description: From real paper books to study abstracts and blog posts; the classic written word enhancing your learning in many ways.

activities.name: Working with Government on Compass
activities.description: This Compass resource outlines government processes and how they affect the work of the public service. They include: Branches of Government and their function; Budget Day, Elections, Estimates, and the Legislative Assembly of BC.

activity_type.name: Read
activity_type.description: From real paper books to study abstracts and blog posts; the classic written word enhancing your learning in many ways.

activities.name: Understanding Your Ministry
activities.description: 1-page assignment guiding you to identify your ministrys structure, and your organization within it.
activities.moderator_notes: Here is an example of an activity that requires a downloadable original from the Learning Centre. These items need to live somewhere so they may be linked from item records.

activity_type.name: Participate
activity_type.description: Activities that require your interactaction, either in person courses, or via elearning, quizzes, or surveys that provide measurable feedback.

steps.name: Step 2
steps.description: Understand your ministry's core functions and how your work fits into your organization's service plan.

activities.name: Ministry Service Plans
activities.description:
For this activity, find your ministrys current service plan, and answer the following reflective questions:

1) What are your ministrys core functions, defined in your service plan?

2) How can developing your own leadership skills where you are now help your ministry fulfill its core functions? Take a moment to consider the connection, and make a note of it. When youre considering the purpose in engaging in leadership development work, come back to your notes and see how awareness of this connection can help focus your efforts.

activity_type.name: Participate
activity_type.description: Activities that require your interactaction, either in person courses, or via elearning, quizzes, or surveys that provide measurable feedback.

steps.name: Step 3
steps.description: Identify 5 key functions of government, and know where to go to identify more.

activities.name: Three Levels of Government
activities.description: This information is from the Parliament of Canadas website and explains the three levels of government in Canada and their responsibilities. The three levels are federal, provincial and municipal.

activity_type.name: Read
activity_type.description: From real paper books to study abstracts and blog posts; the classic written word enhancing your learning in many ways.

activities.name: Public Sector Management: Roles, Responsibilities & Citizen Accountability
activities.description: Public Sector Management: Roles, Responsibilities & Citizen Accountability explains the role each person or agency has  that support the organization in meeting public interest goals.

activity_type.name: Read
activity_type.description: From real paper books to study abstracts and blog posts; the classic written word enhancing your learning in many ways.

activities.name: Truth and Reconciliation Commission (TRC) Calls to Action
activities.description:
In June 2015, the Truth and Reconciliation Commission (TRC) released 10 principles of reconciliation and 94 calls to action that lead to a path of reconciliation. In December 2015, Prime Minister Trudeau accepted all 94 calls and committed that the federal government would, in partnership with Indigenous communities, the provinces, territories, and other vital partners, fully implement the TRC Calls to Action, starting with the implementation of the United Nations Declaration on the Rights of Indigenous Peoples (UNDRIP). The first principle of reconciliation confirms that UNDRIP is the framework for reconciliation for all sectors of Canadian society.

Call to action #57: Professional Development and Training for Public Servants

"We call upon federal, provincial, territorial, and municipal governments to provide education to public servants on the history of Aboriginal peoples, including the history and legacy of residential schools, the United Nations Declaration on the Rights of Indigenous Peoples, Treaties and Aboriginal rights, Indigenous law, and Aboriginal-Crown relations. This will require skills-based training in intercultural competency, conflict resolution, human rights, and anti-racism."

The link provided is for the full text of the Calls to Action.

activity_type.name: Read
activity_type.description: From real paper books to study abstracts and blog posts; the classic written word enhancing your learning in many ways.

activities.name: United Nations Declaration on the Rights of Indigenous Peoples (UNDRIP)
activities.description:
One function of government is to uphold the rights described in the UNDRIP. This document that describes both individual and collective rights of Indigenous peoples around the world. It offers guidance on cooperative relationships with Indigenous peoples to states, the United Nations, and other international organizations based on the principles of equality, partnership, good faith and mutual respect. It addresses the rights of Indigenous peoples on issues such as:
  1. culture
  2. identity
  3. religion
  4. language
  5. health
  6. education
  7. community
The declaration was adopted by resolution of the United Nations General Assembly on September 13, 2007. The 10 principles of UNDRIP serve as guides to assist in repairing the damaged relationship between the Indigenous and non-Indigenous peoples of Canada.

Link provided is for the full document.

activity_type.name: Read
activity_type.description: From real paper books to study abstracts and blog posts; the classic written word enhancing your learning in many ways.

activities.name: Key Functions of Government
activities.description:
For this activity, reflect on what you have learned in the readings in this step as well as previous steps and answer the following reflective questions:

1) What key functions of government are connected to your work?

2) Think about your teams deliverables for the year. How would you explain to each team member how their work connects to key functions of government?

3) Reflect on the importance of knowing how your work contributes to fulfilling key government functions.

NOTE: No link included for this activity: just the questions above!

activity_type.name: Participate
activity_type.description: Activities that require your interactaction, either in person courses, or via elearning, quizzes, or surveys that provide measurable feedback.

steps.name: Step 4
steps.description: Understand the basics of policy and policy decision-making in government.

activities.name: Gender-Based Analysis in the BC Public Service - Introduction
activities.description: This is a short video and article that introduces GBA+ and its implementation across the BC Public Service.

activity_type.name: Watch
activity_type.description: Only the best of video content from YouTube, Vimeo, and any other source that helps the learning goal.

activities.name: Policy Approaches Playbook
activities.description:
The playbook was originally designed for new policy analysts to understand the most common policy approaches and a helpful summary for experienced policy professionals.

The playbook provides a framework to assist policy teams in selecting the most appropriate approach to their particular circumstances. It is an excellent resource for understanding the role of policy in the public service.

activity_type.name: Read
activity_type.description: From real paper books to study abstracts and blog posts; the classic written word enhancing your learning in many ways.

activities.name: Gov 101: Government Essentials
activities.description:
Gov 101: Government Essentials is an online, on demand course offered by the Learning Centre. It is your introduction to the role of government and how it has evolved, what governance and financial governance are, government participants and your role as a public servant. 

In this course, you will work through the following sections: 1) The role and structure of government 2) Laws and legislation  3) Governance and the public servant role , and 4) Financial governance. This course has interactive elements to it such as quizzes.

_joinData.stepcontext: As it says this is an essential part of this step. check it out!

activity_type.name: Participate
activity_type.description: Activities that require your interactaction, either in person courses, or via elearning, quizzes, or surveys that provide measurable feedback.

activities.name: Gender-Based Analysis Plus Online Course
activities.description:
The BC government is committed to ensuring gender equality is reflected in our budgets, policies and programs. To support this important work, the BC Public Service is implementing a policy and budgeting tool: Gender-Based Analysis Plus (GBA+).

The implementation of GBA+ will allow for a broader assessment of how diverse groups of British Columbians may experience policies, programs and initiatives. This means that we, as public service employees, will be able to provide more comprehensive advice to decision-makers, continue to advance evidence-based policy making, and attain better results for British Columbians by being more responsive to their diverse needs and circumstances.

The Federal government has an excellent GBA+ course/toolkit online which is linked in this step.

activity_type.name: Participate
activity_type.description: Activities that require your interactaction, either in person courses, or via elearning, quizzes, or surveys that provide measurable feedback.

activities.name: Gender-Based Analysis Plus In Person Course
activities.description:
This is a two hour course offered by the Learning Centre. This course will provide the information and resources necessary for GBA+ best practices in policy and program development.

To register for this course go to the Learning Centre and search for Gender-Based Analysis Plus.

Note: Given ongoing concerns regarding COVID-19 and advice/efforts to promote social distancing, the Learning Centre is postponing its face-to-face courses for the foreseeable future.

activity_type.name: Participate
activity_type.description: Activities that require your interactaction, either in person courses, or via elearning, quizzes, or surveys that provide measurable feedback.

activities.name: Policy Essentials in the BC Public Service
activities.description:
This short course provides BC public servants with an introduction to the topic of public policy.

The course will provide you with a basic understanding of public policy, the phases of policy development, and the attributes and skills to be successful in a policy role. By the end of this course, you can expect to be able to: - define public policy. - recognize factors that influence the public policy environment. - recognize what policy analysis is and the role of policy analysts. - identify phases of the policy development cycle. - recognize the skills and attributes to be an effective policy analyst.

You can register for this course in the Learning system.

activity_type.name: Participate
activity_type.description: Activities that require your interactaction, either in person courses, or via elearning, quizzes, or surveys that provide measurable feedback.

steps.name: Step 5
steps.description: Consider the legal context in which your decisions are being made.

activities.name: Parliamentary Procedure Workshops: For Provincial Public Servants
activities.description:
These one-hour workshops for provincial public servants, developed and delivered by the Legislative Assembly of British Columbia, are intended to provide for a greater understanding of parliamentary procedure including the legislative and budgetary process in British Columbia and Cabinet and Treasury Board decision-making.

Note: This is a very high demand learning - check back periodically to see when the next sessions are offered.

activity_type.description: Activities that require your interactaction, either in person courses, or via elearning, quizzes, or surveys that provide measurable feedback.

activities.name: Reflection - Minister Responsibilities
activities.description:
Find out which acts your Minister is responsible for and as a result your Ministry.

Reflect on which of these acts impact your work and how.

activity_type.name: Participate
activity_type.description: Activities that require your interactaction, either in person courses, or via elearning, quizzes, or surveys that provide measurable feedback.

steps.name: Step 6
steps.description: Map an example of how a project/policy links to legislation.

activities.name: CIRMOs video - Information Management in the BC Public Service.
activities.description:
CIRMOs 4-part series on YouTube on asks for your best practices/tools used on the job. 

Each video is under 5 minutes:

Part 1: The Digital Age
Part 2: Records Management
Part 3: Privacy
Part 4: Access to Information

activity_type.name: Watch
activity_type.description: Only the best of video content from YouTube, Vimeo, and any other source that helps the learning goal.

activities.name: Legislation In Action
activities.description:
The BC Laws website includes provincial statutes and regulations. It is the unofficial, online version of current consolidations.

Look at the frequently viewed legislation section on the right side of the page. This includes legislation such as the Employment Standards Act, the Child, Family and Community Service Act, Motor Vehicle Act, the Residential Tenancy Act and others.

Choose a piece of legislation. Which Minister is responsible for it? (Hint: You can find out here https://www.leg.bc.ca/parliamentary-business/bills-and-legislation under Acts/Minister Responsibilities)

Go to the Ministry website and see how work being done in the Ministry relates to the legislation.

activity_type.name: Participate
activity_type.description: Activities that require your interactaction, either in person courses, or via elearning, quizzes, or surveys that provide measurable feedback.

activities.name: COVID 19 and Legislation
activities.description:
On March 17, 2020 the government declared a provincial state of emergency to support the provincewide response to the novel coronavirus (COVID-19) pandemic.

B.C.s Response to COVID-19 outlines the information, actions and support available to British Columbians. Look at the information through the lens of legislation. Connect a piece of the B.C. response to COVID-19 to legislation. For example, how has the Employment Standards Act been impacted by COVID-19?

activity_type.name: Participate
activity_type.description: Activities that require your interactaction, either in person courses, or via elearning, quizzes, or surveys that provide measurable feedback.

steps.name: Step 8
steps.description: Explain 3 corporate government priorities and why they matter. Articulate what you need to know.

activities.name: Indigenous/Canadian Histories 101
activities.description:
This video by Sarah Robinson focuses on Indigenous/Canadian history often not told with focus on legislative impacts, important court cases, and implications for Indigenous and Crown relations in BC today.

Very engaging and useful information, gives context on history of relationships within Canada and information on Indigenous and Crown relations in BC, important for understanding government initiatives and Indigenous relations.

activity_type.name: Watch
activity_type.description: Only the best of video content from YouTube, Vimeo, and any other source that helps the learning goal.

activities.name: New Relationship with Indigenous People
activities.description:
As part of its work to create true and lasting reconciliation with Indigenous peoples, the government of British Columbia is committed to adopting and implementing the United Nations Declaration on the Rights of Indigenous Peoples (UN declaration), and the Truth and Reconciliation Commission of Canadas Calls to Action (calls to action).

This website provides important information and links to additional information regarding building relationships with Indigenous people.

activity_type.name: Read
activity_type.description: From real paper books to study abstracts and blog posts; the classic written word enhancing your learning in many ways.

activities.name: BC Government Initiatives, Plans & Strategies
activities.description: This part of the BC Government website introduces and provides links on initiatives, plans and strategies.

activity_type.name: Read
activity_type.description: From real paper books to study abstracts and blog posts; the classic written word enhancing your learning in many ways.

activities.name: Driving team performance through diversity & inclusion - Capital H Podcast
activities.description: Diversity and inclusion (D&I) continues to be a driving force for innovative ideas and team performance in the workplace. Jennifer Chatman, the Paul J. Cortese Distinguished Professor of Management at Berkeley Haas, takes a closer look at D&I and discusses key findings from her research, including the positive effects of collective attitudes in diverse teams, how emphasizing diversity encourages risk-taking and innovation, and how managers can lead their teams to embrace diversity through challenging assumptions in a supportive environment.

activity_type.name: Listen
activity_type.description: There are so many things to listen to from podcasts and audio books to radio shows and even music to help achieve your goals.

activities.name: Gender-Based Analysis Plus Online Course
activities.description:
The BC government is committed to ensuring gender equality is reflected in our budgets, policies and programs. To support this important work, the BC Public Service is implementing a policy and budgeting tool: Gender-Based Analysis Plus (GBA+).

The implementation of GBA+ will allow for a broader assessment of how diverse groups of British Columbians may experience policies, programs and initiatives. This means that we, as public service employees, will be able to provide more comprehensive advice to decision-makers, continue to advance evidence-based policy making, and attain better results for British Columbians by being more responsive to their diverse needs and circumstances.

The Federal government has an excellent GBA+ course/toolkit online which is linked in this step.

activities.name: Reflection on Corporate Priorities
activities.description:
After exploring and learning about corporate priorities choose three to reflect on and answer the questions below.

1) Think about how you would explain these corporate priorities to someone who didnt know about them.

2) Why are these three corporate priorities important?

3) How do these corporate priorities connect to your work?

4) Do you need to learn more about these corporate priorities to effectively do your work? How will you do this?

Note: There is no link for this activity--just the questions above!
